column8: Notes
birthplace; student at the Frères Bretons de l'Instruction Chrétienne; also attended Pinchinat High School and Pétion High School
attends Aimé Césaire's seminar (May-December 1944); publishes Etincelles, founds journal La Ruche
column9: Étincelles (Imprimerie de l'État 1945); Gerbes de Sang (Imprimerie de l'État 1946)
column10: Dewitt Peters, founder of the Centre d'Art) is his English professor in highschool; Nicolás Guillén (1942) invited to PAP by Jacques Roumain; attends Alejo Carpentier's lecture (1943); attends Aimé Césaire's seminar May-Dec 1944); meets Jacques Stephen Alexis, Theodore Baker, Gérald Bloncourt, Gérard Chenet (co-editors of La Ruche), Laurore Saint-Juste

column8: flew here from Port-au-Prince and departed on a boat for Cherbourg
arrived here on a boat from New York; heads to Paris, where picked up by Aimé Césaire
connects w/Bloncourt and Alexis; hangs out w/Francis Joachim Roy and French intelligentsia etc; attended both Sciences Po and La Sorbonne
World Federation of Democratic Youth send him to the International Festival of Students and Youth – spends summer laying rail tracks from Samac to Sarajevo in Yugoslavia
during this period, joins the "Group of Young Poets" created by Elsa Triolet
meets Pablo Neruda, Jorge Amado at Chateau de Dobris
column10: Ilya Ehrenbourg – learns things "of capital importance" regarding Stalinist pervservion of communism across Europe

column8: Third World Festival of Youth and Students for Peace; sees Guillén there [Cuba journal 9/11/1965 mistakenly says he was there summer 1952]
column10: Turkish poet Nazim Hikmet; Anna Seghers, Diego Rivera, Georg Lukács, etc

column8: expelled for criticism of Stalinist purges
embarks on the Francesco Morosini; learns of Batista's coup onboard March 10
invited by Guillén; arrested by Fulgencio Batista; expelled
disembarks from the Francesco Morosini
Maison de la pensée française (connects w/Aragon and Bloncourt); discovered and expelled
World Peace Council (founded by Cominform in 1950 to combat US "warmongering" and nuclearization)– 12/12-12/19
on the invitation of painter Renato Guttuso; stay in the Alcron Hotel [leaves from here to Brazil before heading to Chile: figure out these dates]
column10: Pierre Courtade, who helps him understand that the failures of men of the Party are not the failures of the Bloshevik communist ideals

column8: Congreso Continental de la Cultura organized w/Neruda (as his secretary) and Amado in April 1953

column10: Victoria and Silvina Ocampo, editors of literary magazine Sur

column8: militant in Brazilian Communist Party; writing under the name "Walter Miranda"
granted a visa thanks to Léopold Sedar Senghor's intervention
Moulin d'Andé w/Richard Wright, Maurice Pons, Suzanne Lipinska
First International Conference of Negro Writers and Artists organized by journal Présence Africaine
invited by François Duvalier to return from exile and assume post of Foreign Affairs Minister

invited to participate in revolutionary operations by Che Guevara on Guillén's recommendation; important role in the National Press, serves as Minister of Exterior Relations, journalist for Revolución and Hoy, broadcaster on Radio Cuba, organizer of Congreso Cultural de la Havana (1967)
sent as correspondent with Revolución; meets up w/Alexis to discuss reconciling 2 factions of Haitian communism
meets with Mao Tse-tung and Chou En-lai
Jacques Stephen Alexis arrives to prepare invasion of Haiti
meets with Ho Chi Minh
Bay of Pigs
sent as correspondent for Revolución
Cuban Missile Crisis; Cultural Congress of Havana January 4-11, 1968
sent as journalist for Granma to cover Pan-African Festival of Algiers
meets w/publishers re: Alléluia

column9: Pour la révolution pour la poésie (Leméac 1974); Poète à Cuba (Oswald 1976)

column8: Mona, University of the West Indies
works for UNESCO
column9: Le mât de Cocagne (Gallimard 1979); En état de poésie (Éditeurs français réunis 1980); Bonjour et adieu à la négritude (Laffont 1980, 1989)

column8: attends Congress of Pen Club as representative of UNESCO
attends 8th World Congress of Poets presided over by Senghor as representative of UNESCO

column9: Au matin de la négritude (Euroediteur 1990); Journal d'un animal marin Gallimard 1990)

column8: attends events surrounding Aimé Césaire's 90th birthday
sent w/Foreign Affairs Minister Michel Barnier and writer Régis Debray by Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin to lecture at Institut français d'Haïti on 2005-02-22
lectures at the Centre des Arts et de la Culture on 2005-04-25
lectures at University of Grenada
